Measures of central tendency

1. Revision of mean, mode, median for ungrouped data

The mean

Consider the following raw data:

{7;6;8;6;5;5;11;8}
{7;6;8;6;5;5;11;8}

What is the mean value of the data set? Round your answer to 2 decimal places.

Answer:

Mean:

numeric
STEP: <no title>
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

The most useful step towards solving any data problem is to sort the data first.

{5;5;6;6;7;8;8;11}
{5;5;6;6;7;8;8;11}

Since we are looking for the mean, we need to add up the numbers in the set and divide the total by how many numbers are in the set. The sum of all the values here is 56, and there are 8 values.

Mean=568=7
Mean=568=7

So the mean value of the data is 77.

The mode

Consider this set of raw data:

{5;6;7;7;8;9;9;10;11}
{5;6;7;7;8;9;9;10;11}

What is the mode of the data set?

If there are two or more modes, give all of the mode values, separated by a ';' (a semi-colon).

Answer:

Mode:

list
STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The most useful step towards solving a data problem is to sort the data first.

{5;6;7;7;8;9;9;10;11}
{5;6;7;7;8;9;9;10;11}

The mode is the value that appears the most. The mode of this data set is 7 ; 9 as they each appear 2 times.

So the mode of the data set is 7 ; 9.

The median

The following raw data set includes:

{5;9;7;8;6;9;10;6}
{5;9;7;8;6;9;10;6}

What is the median value of the data set?

Answer:

Median:

numeric
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The most useful step towards solving any data problem is to sort the data first. Here we are looking for the median, so we should put the numbers in order and find the exact middle of the data. Here we have 8 values:

{5;6;6;7;8;9;9;10}
{5;6;6;7;8;9;9;10}

If we have a even number of values, we need to add the middle 2 values and divide by 2.

So the median value is 7,57,5.

Measures of central tendency

Consider the following raw data:

{11;10;6;9;5;11;6;7;8}
{11;10;6;9;5;11;6;7;8}
  1. What is the mode of the data set?
    INSTRUCTION:If there are two or more modes give all of the mode values, separated by ';' (a semi-colon).
  2. What is the mean value of the data set? Round your answer to 2 decimal places.
  3. What is the median value of the data set?
Answer:

Mode:
Mean:
Median:

list
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 7 / 7 points left]

Start by arranging the data in numerical order (from the smallest number to the largest).

STEP: Arrange the data in numerical order
[−1 point ⇒ 6 / 7 points left]

The most useful step towards solving many data problems is to sort the data first. The sorted data are:

{5;6;6;7;8;9;10;11;11}
{5;6;6;7;8;9;10;11;11}
STEP: Find the mode or modes
[−1 point ⇒ 5 / 7 points left]

Find the mode: the mode is the value or values that appear the most. In this data set, there are 2 different values which are modes. 66 and 1111 each occur 2 times.

STEP: Compute the mean
[−3 points ⇒ 2 / 7 points left]

Find the mean: add up the numbers in the set and divide by how many numbers are in the set. The sum of all the values here is 7373 and there are 99 values.

Mean=739=8,11
Mean=739=8,11
STEP: Find the median value
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 7 points left]

Find the median: for the median the numbers must be in order! For the ordered data, the median is the number in the exact middle.

Here we have 99 values: {5;6;6;7;8;9;10;11;11}{5;6;6;7;8;9;10;11;11}. If we have an uneven number of values in our data list, it is easy. We just find the middle value. Here, the median is 88.

Therefore:

  1. The modes of the data set are 66 and 1111.
  2. The mean of the data set is 8,118,11.
  3. The median of the data set is 88.

Working with the mean

A group of 88 friends each have some playing cards. They work out that the mean number of playing cards they have is 44. Then 22 friends leave with an unknown number (xx) of playing cards. The remaining 66 friends work out that the mean number of playing cards they have left is 11.

How many playing cards (xx) were taken away from the group?

Answer:

The number of playing cards taken away is .

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
Use the formula for the mean to figure out the total number of playing cards in the original group.
STEP: Find the total number of playing cards at the beginning
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We know that the mean number of playing cards the group originally had was 44. Since there are 88 people in the group we can find the total number of playing cards in the beginning using the formula for the mean:

mean=(number ofplaying cards (before))group sizenumber ofplaying cards (before)=mean×group size=(4)×(8)=32
meannumber ofplaying cards (before)=(number ofplaying cards (before))group size=mean×group size=(4)×(8)=32
STEP: Find the total number of playing cards after the 2 people leave
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

We are then told that 22 people leave. After that, the mean number of playing cards left is 11. We can then find out how many playing cards remain.

mean=(number ofplaying cards (after))group sizenumber ofplaying cards (after)=mean×group size=(1)×(6)=6
meannumber ofplaying cards (after)=(number ofplaying cards (after))group size=mean×group size=(1)×(6)=6
STEP: Find the number of playing cards taken from the group
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we can work out the number of playing cards which were taken from the original group.

number ofplaying cards removed=items before−items after=(32)−(6)=26
number ofplaying cards removed=items before−items after=(32)−(6)=26

The correct answer is 2626 playing cards.

Submit your answer as:

Working with measures of central tendency of data

Calculate the median of the following data set:

13;13;13;13;611;13;6;13;1;3
13;13;13;13;611;13;6;13;1;3
INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places, if necessary.
Answer: The median is: .
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

To find the median, you must start by arranging the numbers in order from smallest to largest. Then what is the next thing to do?

STEP: Determine the median
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to calculate the median.

First order the data set:

1;3;6;6;1113;13;13;13;13;13
1;3;6;6;1113;13;13;13;13;13

The median of a data set is the value in the central position, when the data set has been arranged from the lowest to the highest value. If we have an uneven number of values in the data list, we just look for the middle value.

The median of the data is: 1313.

numeric
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

{5;5;6;7;8;9;9;10;11;11}
{5;5;6;7;8;9;9;10;11;11}

If we have a even number of values, we need to add the middle 2 values and divide by 2.

So the median value is 8,58,5.

Working with the mean

A group of 66 friends each have some playing cards. They work out that the mean number of playing cards they have is 55. Then 22 friends leave with an unknown number (xx) of playing cards. The remaining 44 friends work out that the mean number of playing cards they have left is 1,51,5.

How many playing cards (xx) were taken away from the group?

Answer:

The number of playing cards taken away is .

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
Use the formula for the mean to figure out the total number of playing cards in the original group.
STEP: Find the total number of playing cards at the beginning
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We know that the mean number of playing cards the group originally had was 55. Since there are 66 people in the group we can find the total number of playing cards in the beginning using the formula for the mean:

mean=(number ofplaying cards (before))group sizenumber ofplaying cards (before)=mean×group size=(5)×(6)=30
meannumber ofplaying cards (before)=(number ofplaying cards (before))group size=mean×group size=(5)×(6)=30
STEP: Find the total number of playing cards after the 2 people leave
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

We are then told that 22 people leave. After that, the mean number of playing cards left is 1,51,5. We can then find out how many playing cards remain.

mean=(number ofplaying cards (after))group sizenumber ofplaying cards (after)=mean×group size=(1,5)×(4)=6
meannumber ofplaying cards (after)=(number ofplaying cards (after))group size=mean×group size=(1,5)×(4)=6
STEP: Find the number of playing cards taken from the group
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we can work out the number of playing cards which were taken from the original group.

number ofplaying cards removed=items before−items after=(30)−(6)=24
number ofplaying cards removed=items before−items after=(30)−(6)=24

The correct answer is 2424 playing cards.

Submit your answer as:

Working with the mean

A group of 77 friends each have some marbles. They work out that the mean number of marbles they have is 22. Then 33 friends leave with an unknown number (xx) of marbles. The remaining 44 friends work out that the mean number of marbles they have left is 11.

How many marbles (xx) were taken away from the group?

Answer:

The number of marbles taken away is .

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
Use the formula for the mean to figure out the total number of marbles in the original group.
STEP: Find the total number of marbles at the beginning
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We know that the mean number of marbles the group originally had was 22. Since there are 77 people in the group we can find the total number of marbles in the beginning using the formula for the mean:

mean=(number ofmarbles (before))group sizenumber ofmarbles (before)=mean×group size=(2)×(7)=14
meannumber ofmarbles (before)=(number ofmarbles (before))group size=mean×group size=(2)×(7)=14
STEP: Find the total number of marbles after the 3 people leave
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

We are then told that 33 people leave. After that, the mean number of marbles left is 11. We can then find out how many marbles remain.

mean=(number ofmarbles (after))group sizenumber ofmarbles (after)=mean×group size=(1)×(4)=4
meannumber ofmarbles (after)=(number ofmarbles (after))group size=mean×group size=(1)×(4)=4
STEP: Find the number of marbles taken from the group
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we can work out the number of marbles which were taken from the original group.

number ofmarbles removed=items before−items after=(14)−(4)=10
number ofmarbles removed=items before−items after=(14)−(4)=10

The correct answer is 1010 marbles.

  3. Which of the measures of central tendency, the modal class, or the estimated mean, will be the most appropriate to describe the data set?

    Answer:

    For describing the data set, .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    You need to compare the measures of central tendency from Questions 1 and 2 to the histogram. Which one corresponds better to the bulk of the data?

    STEP: Compare the answers from Questions 1 and 2 to the histogram
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to determine if the modal class or the estimated mean is more appropriate for the data shown in the histogram. In other words, we need to decide which one gives the best summary of the data.

    Each measure of central tendency tells us something specific about a data set. Sometimes one measure is better than another because of how the data are spread out. Generally we decide which one to use by making sure that we do not hide any important facts about the data.

    Here are the key things to consider about the esimtated mean and the modal interval:

    • The estimated mean always represents every data value in the set. The mean is the most common measure of central tendency. Use it unless there is a good reason not to.

      • Do not use if there is a very tall modal interval with no other tall bars.
      • Do not use if there are some outliers that drag the mean away from a central portion of the data.

    • The modal class ignores the role of values outside of the modal class and focuses on the most common values.

      • Use if there is a single interval which dominates (is much taller than) all other intervals. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.
      • Use if there is more than one modal class to indicate that the data have multiple peaks. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.
      • Do not use if the data are well-balanced and the modal class is only slightly taller than nearby classes. (Use the mean instead.)

    An important fact about these data is that the modal class is much larger than the other intervals. We might use the mean to summarise the data, but if we do that we will hide the fact that the modal class is so dominant. So the better choice in this case is the modal class because it is so much taller than any of the other intervals. In other words, we want to indicate that a certain group of values for the net mass of imports shown in the histogram is much more common than any of the other values.

    NOTE: It is crucial to be aware that the meaning of the modal class is part of the reason why it is the best choice. The modal class is the best choice partly because we know that it indicates the most common values. If we select the modal class as the best choice, we are saying that those common values are one of the most important things about the data.

    The more appropriate value for summarising the data is the modal class.

The estimated mean compared to the true mean

  1. The following shows a list of data values for a quantity xx, as well as their mean.

    1;4;5;6;7;9;11;12;15;17Mean=8,7
    1;4;5;6;7;9;11;12;15;17Mean=8,7

    If you group these data into intervals, you can calculate the estimated mean. Should you expect the estimated mean to be equal to 8,78,7 or will it be different? Select your answer from the table below.

    A The estimated mean will not be equal to 8,78,7.
    B The estimated mean will be equal to 8,78,7.
    C The estimated mean might be equal to 8,78,7 but probably not.
    D None of the above.
    Answer:

    The correct choice is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about the calculation for the estimated mean. How does it compare to the calculation for the mean?

    STEP: Compare the calculations for the true mean and the estimated mean
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to decide how the estimated mean compares to the true mean for a group of data. We calculate the true (exact) value of the mean as follows:

    Mean=1+4+5+...+12+15+1710=8710=8,7
    Mean=1+4+5+...+12+15+1710=8710=8,7

    How does this compare to the estimated mean for grouped data? To answer this let's group the data and work out the estimated mean. Here is one way to group the data:

    Interval Frequency
    0≤x<50≤x<5 22
    5≤x<105≤x<10 44
    10≤x<1510≤x<15 22
    15≤x<2015≤x<20 22

    To find the estimated mean for grouped data we multiply the midpoint of each interval by the number of values in that interval:

    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅2+7,5⋅4+12,5⋅2+17,5⋅2)10=9510=9,5
    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅2+7,5⋅4+12,5⋅2+17,5⋅2)10=9510=9,5

    Compare the two results:

    Mean=8,7Estimated mean=9,5
    MeanEstimated mean=8,7=9,5

    We can see that the results are not equal. The reason they are different is the subject of Question 2 below.

    NOTE:The estimated mean and the true mean are not always different. It is possible that they will be equal although this is a rare coincidence.

    Therefore the correct answer is that the estimated mean might be equal to 8,78,7 but probably not.

  2. Why can the estimated mean be different to the true mean? Choose the best option in the table below to explain why.

    The estimated mean can be different because...
    A it uses multiplication, not only addition.
    B an estimation is never equal to the real answer.
    C it uses estimated data values.
    D it might use a different number of values.
    Answer:

    The correct reasons is choice .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about the numbers we used above in the calculations for the true mean and the estimated mean. How are they different?

    STEP: Think about the differences between the calculations in Question 1
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Normally the estimated mean for grouped data is not equal to the true mean for the original data. What causes this difference? The answer comes from the way we calculate the estimated mean. We saw in Question 1 that this was:

    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅2+7,5⋅4+12,5⋅2+17,5⋅2)10
    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅2+7,5⋅4+12,5⋅2+17,5⋅2)10

    And that means:

    Estimated mean=(2,5+2,5+7,5+7,5+7,5+7,5+12,5+12,5+17,5+17,5)10
    Estimated mean=(2,5+2,5+7,5+7,5+7,5+7,5+12,5+12,5+17,5+17,5)10

    So the estimated mean calculation pretends that the data are:

    2,5;2,5;⏟pretend the dataset contains 2values equal to 2,57,5;7,5;7,5;7,5;⏟pretend the dataset contains 4values equal to 7,512,5;12,5;⏟pretend the dataset contains 2values equal to 12,517,5;17,5⏟pretend the dataset contains 2values equal to 17,5
    2,5;2,5;⏟pretend the dataset contains 2values equal to 2,57,5;7,5;7,5;7,5;⏟pretend the dataset contains 4values equal to 7,512,5;12,5;pretend the dataset contains 2values equal to 12,517,5;17,5pretend the dataset contains 2values equal to 17,5

    We pretend these are the values of the data because from the grouped data alone we do not know the data values. We pretend that the 22 values in the first interval all have a value of 2,52,5. This is very unlikely to match the real data, but 2,52,5 is the most sensible estimate for those numbers. Similarly, we pretend that the 44 values in the second interval all have a value of 7,57,5. That is also unlikely to match the real data, but 7,57,5 is the best estimate we can make for the numbers in that interval. We do the same thing for each interval. So we use the midpoint of each interval as the best estimate for the (unknown) data values in that interval.

    The estimated mean can be different to the true mean of a data set because it uses estimated data values.

Measures of central tendency: grouped data

The following statement is about the mean for a grouped data set. Is the statement true or false?

Statement: The true mean for a data set must be in the central (middle) interval.
Answer: The statement is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Make up a data set and see where the mean falls compared to the estimated mean.

STEP: Create a data set which can help answer the question
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This question is about how the mean for a data set compares to the estimated mean when the same data are grouped. It takes some imagination to figure out the answer.

Suppose you have a data set with 1515 values and you group the data into three intervals. Can you think of a way for those data to have a mean which is not in the middle interval? Here is a data set which can help us decide:

1;1;1;1;1;2;2;2;5;5;6;6;10;10;10mean=4,2
1;1;1;1;1;2;2;2;5;5;6;6;10;10;10mean=4,2

If we group these data into three intervals, where each interval has a width of 55, we get:

We can see above that the mean is 4,24,2. So the mean is not in the middle interval. This can happen if the values are spread out in an unbalanced way, as in this data set. (There are a lot more data values in the first interval than in the other intervals.)

Therefore the statement that the true mean for a data set must be in the central (middle) interval is false.

If 6767 data values for a quantity xx are grouped in intervals of width 1212 and starting at 2020, the estimated mean for the data is 48,7548,75. Now we regroup the same data in different intervals with width 1212 and starting at 1010. This is shown in the table below.

    Submit your answer as: and

  2. Question 1 stated that the same data grouped with intervals starting at 2020 and 1212 wide produce an estimated mean of 48,7548,75. This is not equal to the answer to Question 1, even though they are both estimates of the mean for the same data set. This shows that the result for the estimated mean depends on how the data are grouped.

    Which of these statements explains why the different groupings can lead to different results for the estimated mean? Identify all correct statements.

    A The total number of data values changes.
    B The location of the median data value might change.
    C Some of the data values might shift from one group to another.
    Answer: The correct choice is .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about the estimated mean calculation. What numbers go into it? How does regrouping the data effect those numbers?

    STEP: Think about the values used to calculate the estimated mean
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    In Question 1 we found that the estimated mean for grouped data was different depending on how we group the data. And we need to identify why this is true.

    To do so, let's think about the calculation of the estimated mean. Any time we calculate an estimated mean for grouped data we use the midpoints of the intervals and the frequencies of the data for each of those intervals. So let's make some variables:

    • Let m1,m2m1,m2... be the midpoints of the intervals
    • Let f1,f2f1,f2... be the frequencies for the intervals.

    Then, if there are 44 intervals, we get:

    Estimated Mean=m1f1+m2f2+m3f3+m4f4f1+f2+f3+f4
    Estimated Mean=m1f1+m2f2+m3f3+m4f4f1+f2+f3+f4

    This equation shows that the midpoints and the frequencies impact the value we get for the estimated mean. In other words, the estimated mean depends on the midpoint values and the frequencies. So if any one of those values changes when the data are regrouped it will affect the estimated mean result.

    Changing the intervals we use for grouping a data set can lead to changes for both the midpoint values and the frequencies. For the statements given in the question:

    Statement Explanation
    A The total number of data values changes. No! Changing the grouping intervals does not change the total number of data values.
    B The location of the median data value might change. No! Which interval the median is in might change when the data are regrouped, but the estimated mean does not depend on the median.
    C Some of the data values might shift from one group to another. Correct! See explanation above.
    NOTE: It is not true that all midpoint values must change when we regroup data. Similarly, it is not true that all frequency values must change when we regroup data. In fact, it is possible that some midpoint values will be the same for both groupings. And it is possible that only a few data values, or none at all, will shift into new groups. But if there are at least two intervals, then at least one of these things must change.

    The correct answer choice is Statement C only.

Where is the median?

The histogram below shows 2121 data values grouped into 55 intervals.

Since there are 2121 data values, the median value is the eleventh value in the data set. Does the median value come before, after, or in the interval 6≤x<86≤x<8?

Answer:

The median the interval 6≤x<86≤x<8.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Count how many values there are before the interval 6≤x<86≤x<8.

STEP: Count how many values are in the intervals up to and in 6≤x<86≤x<8
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to determine if the median value in the data set comes before the interval 6≤x<86≤x<8, after this interval, or in this interval.

The histogram shows us how many data values are in each interval, ordered from smallest to largest. So we can use it to figure out the positions of the first and last values in the interval 6≤x<86≤x<8:

  • The first value in the interval 6≤x<86≤x<8 is the 13th13th data value because there are 1212 values in the first 33 intervals.
  • The last data value in 6≤x<86≤x<8 must be the 12+5=12+5= 17th17th value because there are 55 more data values in the interval 6≤x<86≤x<8.

We know that the median is the eleventh value in the data set. That is less than 1313.

So the median comes before the interval 6≤x<86≤x<8.

Identifying a good summary for grouped data

Students in a biology class are doing an experiment about growing plants. They plant a large number of seeds and then track how many days it takes for the seeds to sprout out of the ground. The histogram below shows these data for the 4242 seeds which sprouted.

Which one of the three measures of central tendency is most appropriate for summarising these data? (Choose your answer from the list below.)

TIP: The answer depends on the shape of the histogram, the type of data, or possibly both.
Answer:

The most appropriate choice is the .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Compare the shape of the histogram to the three choices. Is there anything that indicates that the modal interval tells us more about the data than the estimated mean or the median interval?

STEP: Examine the meaning of each measure of central tendency
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to determine which one of the three measures of central tendency is most appropriate for the data shown in the histogram. In other words, which one gives the best summary of the data?

Each measure of central tendency tells us something specific about a data set. Sometimes one measure is better than another because of how the data are spread out. Generally we decide which one to use by making sure that we do not hide an important fact about the data.

Here are key things to consider about the different measures of central tendency:

  • The estimated mean always represents every data value in the set. The mean is the most common measure of central tendency. Use it unless there is a good reason not to.

    • Do not use if there is a very tall modal interval with no other tall bars.
    • Do not use if there are outliers that drag the mean away from a central part of the data.

  • The modal interval ignores the role of values outside of the modal interval. It focuses on the most common values.

    • Use if there is a single interval which dominates (is much taller than) all other intervals. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.
    • Use if there is more than one modal interval to show that the data have more than one peak. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.
    • Do not use if the data are balanced and the modal interval is only slightly taller than nearby intervals. (Use the mean instead.)

  • The median interval highlights the central values within the data.

    • Use if the data are rankings on a scale, like rating a movie from 11 to 55 stars.
    • Use if the data are shifted to one side or the other (not symmetric around the middle).

The modal interval for these data is the highest interval. So it is not a good representation of the data because they are spread out from 44 to 1010 but the modal interval suggests that the values are clustered around 1313. In other words, the modal interval suggests that a certain group of values for the number of days is much more common than any of the other values but that is not true. While that group of values is the most common, there are other intervals which are nearly as common. In contrast, the estimated mean is 6,386,38, which is closer to the centre of the intervals. So the data are more well-balanced around the mean than they are around the modal interval.

NOTE: It is crucial to be aware that the meaning of the estimated mean is part of the reason why it is the best choice. The estimated mean is the best choice partly because we know that the calculation of the estimated mean is based on every data value. If we select the estimated mean as the best choice, we are saying that the modal interval is not very important (it does not stand out) and the median interval does not tell us anything that the estimated mean does not.

The most appropriate choice is the estimated mean.

Interval Frequency

    Answer: The estimated mean = .

    HINT: <no title>

    The definition of the mean is the sum of a set of values, divided by the number of values in the set. So start by finding the sum and number of values in the table.

    STEP: Find the midpoints of the intervals
    [−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

    In this question we are given a frequency table, and asked to estimate the mean value of the data.

    The mean of a set of values is the sum of the values, divided by the number of values in the data set. So the first step is to calculate the sum of all the values.

    Interval Frequency

    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

    Sum=((1⋅7)+(3⋅4)+(5⋅7)+(7⋅8)+(9⋅5))

  2. Is the value calculated in Question 1 the exact value of the mean for the data set? Choose a reason from the table below.

    Reason
    A There is no true mean since we don't know the data.
    B The estimated mean is always the same as the mean.
    C The midpoints are an estimation of the data values.

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Did you use the exact values in your calculation for Question 1? Or did you have to make some assumptions?

    STEP: Identify the difference between exact and estimated mean
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    When we have data grouped into intervals, we do not know the exact values of each of the data points. Instead, we only know the interval in which each value lies.

    When we calculate the exact mean of a data set, we use the exact values of the data points. But for grouped data, we do not know the individual data values. So we use the midpoints of the intervals instead. This is an estimation and it usually gives a different result from the true mean.

    It is possible that the estimated mean will be equal to the true mean. But if that happens it is a coincidence. And since we do not know the original data, we would not even know that the estimated mean was equal to the exact value!

    The correct answer is that the estimated mean value is not exact, because the midpoints are an estimation of the data values (Reason C).

Working with grouped data

The figure below shows a histogram which summarises a set of data values. The data values are real numbers. The data are grouped into 55 intervals. Answer the two questions below about the histogram.

  1. Estimate the mean value of the data.

    INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places if necessary.
    Answer: The estimated mean = .
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

    The definition of the mean is the sum of all the values in a set, divided by the number of values. So start by estimating the sum and number of values from the histogram.

    STEP: Read the sum and number of values from the histogram
    [−2 points ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

    The question asks us to estimate the mean of the data values from the histogram. The mean of a set of values is the sum of the values over the number of values in the set. So we need to find the sum and number of the data values.

    For data in a histogram, the data intervals are shown on the horizontal axis. And the frequency of these intervals is measured on the vertical axis. Each value in a given interval is assumed to have the midpoint value of that interval. We do this because the individual value details are lost when we group the data.

    This means that the estimated sum of the data in each histogram bar is the height of the bar (the frequency) multiplied by the midpoint on the horizontal axis of that bar. We add all those together to estimate the sum for the entire data set.

    Sum=((2⋅5)+(6⋅9)+(10⋅3)+(14⋅7)+(18⋅4))=264
    Sum=⎛⎝⎜⎜(2⋅5)+(6⋅9)+(10⋅3)+(14⋅7)+(18⋅4)⎞⎠⎟⎟=264

    The total number of values is the the total frequency value - this is the sum of the heights of the bars on the histogram.

    Number=5+9+3+7+4=28
    Number=5+9+3+7+4=28
    STEP: Estimate the mean value
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

    So now we have all the information we need to calculate the estimated mean value.

    Estimatedmean=SumNumber=26428=9,42857...≈9,43
    Estimatedmean=SumNumber=26428=9,42857...≈9,43

    So the estimated mean value is 9,439,43.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Is it possible that the mode of the data is 55?

    Answer: 55 be the mode of the data.
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    The modal interval is the interval with the most values in it. Can you think of a scenario where the mode of the data set is not in the modal interval?

    STEP: Determine whether the mode can be equal to 55
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The question asks us whether 55 can be the mode of the given set of values. The mode of a set of values is the value with the highest frequency.

    Let's take another look at the histogram. The modal interval is the interval 4≤x<84≤x<8 - it is the interval with the tallest bar on the histogram. This is also the interval which contains the value 55.

    So it is completely possible that the mode is equal to 55, since the value 55 is in the interval with the highest frequency.

    However, we need to be careful when we think about the mode and the modal interval for grouped data. The mode does not have to be in the modal interval. It is possible, but it is not a requirement.

    Let's take a look at a simple example to see why this is true.

    Suppose you have a data set with 1515 values and you group the data into three intervals.

    Can you think of a way for those data to have a modal interval in one place but a mode in another place?

    Here is a data set which can help us decide

    3;3;3;5;6;7;7;8;9;9;11;11;12;13;14
    3;3;3;5;6;7;7;8;9;9;11;11;12;13;14

    If we group these data into three intervals, where each interval has a width of 55, we get:

    The modal interval is the middle interval 5≤x<105≤x<10. But the mode is 33! The mode is not in the modal interval! This can happen because the modal interval contains the most values, but those values might not all be the same. So while the modal interval contains more values that any other interval, it does not have to contain a large number of any single value (which is what the mode is).

    So the correct answer is yes, 55 can be the mode of the data.

The mean is defined as the sum of a set of values, divided by the number of values in the set. In the case of grouped data, like the ones shown in the frequency table, we do not know the exact value of each data point. Instead we have to assume that each point in a given interval has the value of the midpoint of the interval. We use the midpoint because it is assumed to be the average value within the interval.

To find the estimated mean of a set of grouped data, we must multiply the midpoint of each interval by the frequency of that interval. The frequency is the number of times each midpoint value occurs in the data set.Then we add all those numbers up and divide that total by the total number of values in the set.

We are told that there are a total of 2121 values in the data set.

Let's add the midpoint values to the frequency table:

Interval Frequency
0≤x<20≤x<2
Midpoint: 11 		33
2≤x<42≤x<4
Midpoint: 33 		66
4≤x<64≤x<6
Midpoint: 55 		55
6≤x<86≤x<8
Midpoint: 77 		77

If we calculate the estimated mean using the information from the frequency table, we end up with the following equation:

Estimatedmean=((1⋅3)+(3⋅6)+(5⋅5)+(7⋅7))21
Estimatedmean=((1⋅3)+(3⋅6)+(5⋅5)+(7⋅7))21

Comparing this to the expression given in the question, we can see that the missing value is 33.

So the correct answer is n=3n=3.

STEP: Identify whether the value is a midpoint or a frequency
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Now we need to determine whether nn is a midpoint or a frequency.

Comparing the value of nn to the new information in the table, we can see that nn is a midpoint.

So the correct answer is that nn is a midpoint.

  3. Which of the measures of central tendency, the modal class, or the estimated mean, will be the most appropriate to describe the data set?

    Answer:

    For describing the data set, .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    You need to compare the measures of central tendency from Questions 1 and 2 to the histogram. Which one corresponds better to the bulk of the data?

    STEP: Compare the answers from Questions 1 and 2 to the histogram
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to determine if the modal class or the estimated mean is more appropriate for the data shown in the histogram. In other words, we need to decide which one gives the best summary of the data.

    Each measure of central tendency tells us something specific about a data set. Sometimes one measure is better than another because of how the data are spread out. Generally we decide which one to use by making sure that we do not hide any important facts about the data.

    Here are the key things to consider about the esimtated mean and the modal interval:

    • The estimated mean always represents every data value in the set. The mean is the most common measure of central tendency. Use it unless there is a good reason not to.

      • Do not use if there is a very tall modal interval with no other tall bars.
      • Do not use if there are some outliers that drag the mean away from a central portion of the data.

    • The modal class ignores the role of values outside of the modal class and focuses on the most common values.

      • Use if there is a single interval which dominates (is much taller than) all other intervals. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.
      • Use if there is more than one modal class to indicate that the data have multiple peaks. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.
      • Do not use if the data are well-balanced and the modal class is only slightly taller than nearby classes. (Use the mean instead.)

    The modal class for these data is the lowest interval. But the data are spread out from 50 to 1400 and include lots of values in other intervals. If we use the modal class to summarise the data we are suggesting that a certain group of values for the gross vehicle mass is much more common than any of the other values. While that group of values is the most common, there are other intervals which are nearly as common. In contrast, the estimated mean is 850,9850,9, which is closer to the centre of the intervals. So the data are more well-balanced around the mean than they are around the modal class.

    NOTE: It is crucial to be aware that the meaning of the estimated mean is part of the reason why it is the best choice. The estimated mean is the best choice partly because we know that the mean includes every data value. If we select the estimated mean as the best choice, we are saying that the mode is not very important (it does not stand out) and the median does not tells us anything that the mean does not.

    The more appropriate value for summarising the data is the estimated mean.

    Submit your answer as:

The estimated mean compared to the true mean

  1. The following shows a list of data values for a quantity xx, as well as their mean.

    2;3;3;5;5;7;8;10;10;15Mean=6,8
    2;3;3;5;5;7;8;10;10;15Mean=6,8

    If you group these data into intervals, you can calculate the estimated mean. Should you expect the estimated mean to be equal to 6,86,8 or will it be different? Select your answer from the table below.

    A The estimated mean will be equal to 6,86,8.
    B The estimated mean will not be equal to 6,86,8.
    C The estimated mean might be equal to 6,86,8 but probably not.
    D None of the above.
    Answer:

    The correct choice is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about the calculation for the estimated mean. How does it compare to the calculation for the mean?

    STEP: Compare the calculations for the true mean and the estimated mean
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to decide how the estimated mean compares to the true mean for a group of data. We calculate the true (exact) value of the mean as follows:

    Mean=2+3+3+...+10+10+1510=6810=6,8
    Mean=2+3+3+...+10+10+1510=6810=6,8

    How does this compare to the estimated mean for grouped data? To answer this let's group the data and work out the estimated mean. Here is one way to group the data:

    Interval Frequency
    0≤x<50≤x<5 33
    5≤x<105≤x<10 44
    10≤x<1510≤x<15 22
    15≤x<2015≤x<20 11

    To find the estimated mean for grouped data we multiply the midpoint of each interval by the number of values in that interval:

    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅3+7,5⋅4+12,5⋅2+17,5⋅1)10=8010=8
    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅3+7,5⋅4+12,5⋅2+17,5⋅1)10=8010=8

    Compare the two results:

    Mean=6,8Estimated mean=8
    MeanEstimated mean=6,8=8

    We can see that the results are not equal. The reason they are different is the subject of Question 2 below.

    NOTE:The estimated mean and the true mean are not always different. It is possible that they will be equal although this is a rare coincidence.

    Therefore the correct answer is that the estimated mean might be equal to 6,86,8 but probably not.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Why can the estimated mean be different to the true mean? Choose the best option in the table below to explain why.

    The estimated mean can be different because...
    A it uses estimated data values.
    B it might use a different number of values.
    C it uses multiplication, not only addition.
    D an estimation is never equal to the real answer.
    Answer:

    The correct reasons is choice .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about the numbers we used above in the calculations for the true mean and the estimated mean. How are they different?

    STEP: Think about the differences between the calculations in Question 1
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Normally the estimated mean for grouped data is not equal to the true mean for the original data. What causes this difference? The answer comes from the way we calculate the estimated mean. We saw in Question 1 that this was:

    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅3+7,5⋅4+12,5⋅2+17,5⋅1)10
    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅3+7,5⋅4+12,5⋅2+17,5⋅1)10

    And that means:

    Estimated mean=(2,5+2,5+2,5+7,5+7,5+7,5+7,5+12,5+12,5+17,5)10
    Estimated mean=(2,5+2,5+2,5+7,5+7,5+7,5+7,5+12,5+12,5+17,5)10

    So the estimated mean calculation pretends that the data are:

    2,5;2,5;2,5;⏟pretend the dataset contains 3values equal to 2,57,5;7,5;7,5;7,5;⏟pretend the dataset contains 4values equal to 7,512,5;12,5;⏟pretend the dataset contains 2values equal to 12,517,5⏟pretend the dataset contains 1value equal to 17,5
    2,5;2,5;2,5;pretend the dataset contains 3values equal to 2,57,5;7,5;7,5;7,5;⏟pretend the dataset contains 4values equal to 7,512,5;12,5;pretend the dataset contains 2values equal to 12,517,5⏟pretend the dataset contains 1value equal to 17,5

    We pretend these are the values of the data because from the grouped data alone we do not know the data values. We pretend that the 33 values in the first interval all have a value of 2,52,5. This is very unlikely to match the real data, but 2,52,5 is the most sensible estimate for those numbers. Similarly, we pretend that the 44 values in the second interval all have a value of 7,57,5. That is also unlikely to match the real data, but 7,57,5 is the best estimate we can make for the numbers in that interval. We do the same thing for each interval. So we use the midpoint of each interval as the best estimate for the (unknown) data values in that interval.

    The estimated mean can be different to the true mean of a data set because it uses estimated data values.

The estimated mean compared to the true mean

  1. The following shows a list of data values for a quantity xx, as well as their mean.

    1;1;1;4;4;5;6;7;18;19Mean=6,6
    1;1;1;4;4;5;6;7;18;19Mean=6,6

    If you group these data into intervals, you can calculate the estimated mean. Should you expect the estimated mean to be equal to 6,66,6 or will it be different? Select your answer from the table below.

    A The estimated mean might be equal to 6,66,6 but probably not.
    B The estimated mean will not be equal to 6,66,6.
    C The estimated mean will be equal to 6,66,6.
    D None of the above.
    Answer:

    The correct choice is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about the calculation for the estimated mean. How does it compare to the calculation for the mean?

    STEP: Compare the calculations for the true mean and the estimated mean
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to decide how the estimated mean compares to the true mean for a group of data. We calculate the true (exact) value of the mean as follows:

    Mean=1+1+1+...+7+18+1910=6610=6,6
    Mean=1+1+1+...+7+18+1910=6610=6,6

    How does this compare to the estimated mean for grouped data? To answer this let's group the data and work out the estimated mean. Here is one way to group the data:

    Interval Frequency
    0≤x<50≤x<5 55
    5≤x<105≤x<10 33
    10≤x<1510≤x<15 00
    15≤x<2015≤x<20 22

    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅5+7,5⋅3+12,5⋅0+17,5⋅2)10=7010=7
    Estimated mean=(2,5⋅5+7,5⋅3+12,5⋅0+17,5⋅2)10=7010=7

    Mean=6,6Estimated mean=7
    MeanEstimated mean=6,6=7

    We can see that the results are not equal. The reason they are different is the subject of Question 2 below.

    Therefore the correct answer is that the estimated mean might be equal to 6,66,6 but probably not.

Measures of central tendency: grouped data

The following statement is about the mean for a grouped data set. Is the statement true or false?

Statement: The true mean for a data set must be in the central (middle) interval.
Answer: The statement is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Make up a data set and see where the mean falls compared to the estimated mean.

STEP: Create a data set which can help answer the question
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This question is about how the mean for a data set compares to the estimated mean when the same data are grouped. It takes some imagination to figure out the answer.

Suppose you have a data set with 1515 values and you group the data into three intervals. Can you think of a way for those data to have a mean which is not in the middle interval? Here is a data set which can help us decide:

1;1;1;1;1;2;2;2;5;5;6;6;10;10;10mean=4,2
1;1;1;1;1;2;2;2;5;5;6;6;10;10;10mean=4,2

If we group these data into three intervals, where each interval has a width of 55, we get:

We can see above that the mean is 4,24,2. So the mean is not in the middle interval. This can happen if the values are spread out in an unbalanced way, as in this data set. (There are a lot more data values in the first interval than in the other intervals.)

Therefore the statement that the true mean for a data set must be in the central (middle) interval is false.

Submit your answer as:

Comparing the estimated mean to the true mean of a data set

Students in physics class collected data about objects falling due to gravity. They dropped objects from various heights and measured the velocity (speed) of the objects just before they hit the ground. The data below show these velocities in metres per second for 1515 objects.

Speed of object (m·s⁻¹)5,5;5,7;6,2;6,5;8,4;8,7;10,2;10,2;12,9;13,5;13,7;13,8;14,3;14,3;14,7

    Answer: The mean is m·s⁻¹
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    STEP: Calculate the mean of the data
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    Mean=(5,5+5,7+6,2+...+14,3+14,3+14,7)15=158,615=10,57333...≈10,57
    Mean=(5,5+5,7+6,2+...+14,3+14,3+14,7)15=158,615=10,57333...≈10,57

  3. The estimated mean from Question 2 is not equal to the mean you calculated in Question 1. Which statement below best describes the relationship between the two values?

    A The estimated mean is very unlikely to be equal to the mean because the calculation uses the midpoints in place of the data values
    B The estimated mean should be equal to the true mean; if they are not equal there is a mistake
    C The estimated mean is never equal to the true mean because it uses the midpoints in place of the data values
    D The estimated mean is not equal to the true mean in this case, but usually they are equal
    Answer: The best choice is .

    Think about how the estimated mean is calculated: why do we use the midpoints of the intervals?

    STEP: Identify the best description of the relationship
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to find the statement which most accurately describes the relationship between the estimated mean for grouped data and the exact (true) mean for the original data.

    We calculate them differently because for the grouped data we do not know the individual data values. So we use the midpoints of the intervals. This is an estimation and it usually gives a different result from the true mean.

    NOTE: It is possible that the estimated mean will be equal to the true mean. But if that happens it is a coincidence. And if we did not know the original data we would not even know that the estimated mean was equal to the true value!

  3. The estimated mean from Question 2 is not equal to the mean you calculated in Question 1. Which statement below best describes the relationship between the two values?

    A The estimated mean is never equal to the true mean because it uses the midpoints in place of the data values
    B The estimated mean should be equal to the true mean; if they are not equal there is a mistake
    C The estimated mean is not equal to the true mean in this case, but usually they are equal
    D The estimated mean is very unlikely to be equal to the mean because the calculation uses the midpoints in place of the data values
    Answer: The best choice is .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about how the estimated mean is calculated: why do we use the midpoints of the intervals?

    STEP: Identify the best description of the relationship
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to find the statement which most accurately describes the relationship between the estimated mean for grouped data and the exact (true) mean for the original data.

    We calculate them differently because for the grouped data we do not know the individual data values. So we use the midpoints of the intervals. This is an estimation and it usually gives a different result from the true mean.

    NOTE: It is possible that the estimated mean will be equal to the true mean. But if that happens it is a coincidence. And if we did not know the original data we would not even know that the estimated mean was equal to the true value!

    Therefore the best choice is D.

Shifting estimates

If 9393 data values for a quantity aa are grouped in intervals of width 1515 and starting at 55, the estimated mean for the data is 40,0840,08. Now we regroup the same data in different intervals with width 1212 and starting at 1010. This is shown in the table below.

    1. The missing frequency is .
    2. The estimated mean for this grouping of these data is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

    The total number of data values is 9393. Use this to answer the first question. Then use the information in the table to calculate the estimated mean.

    STEP: Determine the missing frequency

    Submit your answer as: and

  2. Question 1 stated that the same data grouped with intervals starting at 55 and 1515 wide produce an estimated mean of 40,0840,08. This is not equal to the answer to Question 1, even though they are both estimates of the mean for the same data set. This shows that the result for the estimated mean depends on how the data are grouped.

    Which of these statements explains why the different groupings can lead to different results for the estimated mean? Identify all correct statements.

    A Some of the data values might shift from one group to another.
    B The midpoint values for at least some of the groups will change.
    C The total number of data values changes.
    Answer: The correct choice is .
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about the estimated mean calculation. What numbers go into it? How does regrouping the data effect those numbers?

    STEP: Think about the values used to calculate the estimated mean
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    In Question 1 we found that the estimated mean for grouped data was different depending on how we group the data. And we need to identify why this is true.

    To do so, let's think about the calculation of the estimated mean. Any time we calculate an estimated mean for grouped data we use the midpoints of the intervals and the frequencies of the data for each of those intervals. So let's make some variables:

    • Let m1,m2m1,m2... be the midpoints of the intervals
    • Let f1,f2f1,f2... be the frequencies for the intervals.

    Then, if there are 44 intervals, we get:

    Estimated Mean=m1f1+m2f2+m3f3+m4f4f1+f2+f3+f4
    Estimated Mean=m1f1+m2f2+m3f3+m4f4f1+f2+f3+f4

    This equation shows that the midpoints and the frequencies impact the value we get for the estimated mean. In other words, the estimated mean depends on the midpoint values and the frequencies. So if any one of those values changes when the data are regrouped it will affect the estimated mean result.

    Changing the intervals we use for grouping a data set can lead to changes for both the midpoint values and the frequencies. For the statements given in the question:

    Statement Explanation
    A Some of the data values might shift from one group to another. Correct! See explanation above.
    B The midpoint values for at least some of the groups will change. Correct! See explanation above.
    C The total number of data values changes. No! Changing the grouping intervals does not change the total number of data values.
    NOTE: It is not true that all midpoint values must change when we regroup data. Similarly, it is not true that all frequency values must change when we regroup data. In fact, it is possible that some midpoint values will be the same for both groupings. And it is possible that only a few data values, or none at all, will shift into new groups. But if there are at least two intervals, then at least one of these things must change.

    The correct answer choice is Statements A and B.

    Submit your answer as:

Where is the median?

The histogram below shows 1515 data values grouped into 55 intervals.

Since there are 1515 data values, the median value is the eighth value in the data set. Does the median value come before, after, or in the interval 4≤x<64≤x<6?

Answer:

The median the interval 4≤x<64≤x<6.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Count how many values there are before the interval 4≤x<64≤x<6.

STEP: Count how many values are in the intervals up to and in 4≤x<64≤x<6
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to determine if the median value in the data set comes before the interval 4≤x<64≤x<6, after this interval, or in this interval.

The histogram shows us how many data values are in each interval, ordered from smallest to largest. So we can use it to figure out the positions of the first and last values in the interval 4≤x<64≤x<6:

  • The first value in the interval 4≤x<64≤x<6 is the sixth data value because there are 55 values in the first 22 intervals.
  • The last data value in 4≤x<64≤x<6 must be the 5+6=5+6= eleventh value because there are 66 more data values in the interval 4≤x<64≤x<6.

We know that the median is the eighth value in the data set. That is between 66 and 1111.

So the median is in the interval 4≤x<64≤x<6.

STEP: Find the interval with the most data values in it
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

We need to identify the modal interval for the data shown in the histogram above. The modal interval is the interval (or intervals) which has the largest number of data values in it.

NOTE: The name modal interval comes from the word mode.

Each bar on the histogram shows how many data values are in a single interval. So the tallest bar or bars that we see show us the modal interval(s). In this case, the tallest bar is the second one.

Therefore the modal interval is 3≤x<63≤x<6.

STEP: Read off how many values are in the modal interval
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We can read the number of values in the modal interval from the vertical axis: it shows the frequency of the data values in each interval. The arrow in the picture above shows where to find that information. The number of values in the interval 3≤x<63≤x<6 is 77.

The modal interval for this data set is 3≤x<63≤x<6 and it contains 77 values.

Modes and medians

4343 data values are grouped into 66 intervals. Each interval has a width of 1010. The results are shown in the histogram below. Note that the first interval is labelled A, the second is labelled B, and so on.

  1. Identify the modal interval or intervals.
  2. Give any possible value for the median of the data if the data values are all integers. There may be more than one correct value, but you should give only one answer.
Answer:
  1. The modal interval(s) is/are .
  2. One possible value for the median is .
one-of
type(numeric.noerror)
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by finding the modal interval. Keep in mind that there can be more than one modal interval. For the second question, you need to find the interval which contains the median.

STEP: Find the modal interval or intervals
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

The modal interval is the interval with the most values in it. If there is more than one interval with a maximum number of values then there is more than one modal interval.

We can identify the modal interval or intervals on a histogram by looking for the tallest bars. The height of the bars indicate how many values are in the interval. In this case, the modal interval is interval B, as highlighted below.

In this case, interval B only has more values than any other interval.

NOTE: The name modal interval comes from the word mode.
STEP: Find the interval where the median is

Identifying a good summary for grouped data

The City of Pretoria has been counting the number of cars which pass through a certain intersection each morning from 08:0008:00 until 09:0009:00. The histogram below shows these data for 101101 different days.

Which one of the three measures of central tendency is most appropriate for summarising these data? (Choose your answer from the list below.)

TIP: The answer depends on the shape of the histogram, the type of data, or possibly both.
Answer:

The most appropriate choice is the .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Compare the shape of the histogram to the three choices. Is there anything that indicates that the modal interval tells us more about the data than the estimated mean or the median interval?

STEP: Examine the meaning of each measure of central tendency
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to determine which one of the three measures of central tendency is most appropriate for the data shown in the histogram. In other words, which one gives the best summary of the data?

Each measure of central tendency tells us something specific about a data set. Sometimes one measure is better than another because of how the data are spread out. Generally we decide which one to use by making sure that we do not hide an important fact about the data.

Here are key things to consider about the different measures of central tendency:

  • The estimated mean always represents every data value in the set. The mean is the most common measure of central tendency. Use it unless there is a good reason not to.

    • Do not use if there is a very tall modal interval with no other tall bars.
    • Do not use if there are outliers that drag the mean away from a central part of the data.

  • The modal interval ignores the role of values outside of the modal interval. It focuses on the most common values.

    • Use if there is a single interval which dominates (is much taller than) all other intervals. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.
    • Use if there is more than one modal interval to show that the data have more than one peak. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.
    • Do not use if the data are balanced and the modal interval is only slightly taller than nearby intervals. (Use the mean instead.)

  • The median interval highlights the central values within the data.

    • Use if the data are rankings on a scale, like rating a movie from 11 to 55 stars.
    • Use if the data are shifted to one side or the other (not symmetric around the middle).

The modal interval for these data is the highest interval. So it is not a good representation of the data because they are spread out from 5050 to 250250 but the modal interval suggests that the values are clustered around 275275. In other words, the modal interval suggests that a certain group of values for the number of cars is much more common than any of the other values but that is not true. While that group of values is the most common, there are other intervals which are nearly as common. In contrast, the estimated mean is 142,82142,82, which is closer to the centre of the intervals. So the data are more well-balanced around the mean than they are around the modal interval.

NOTE: It is crucial to be aware that the meaning of the estimated mean is part of the reason why it is the best choice. The estimated mean is the best choice partly because we know that the calculation of the estimated mean is based on every data value. If we select the estimated mean as the best choice, we are saying that the modal interval is not very important (it does not stand out) and the median interval does not tell us anything that the estimated mean does not.

The most appropriate choice is the estimated mean.

The most appropriate choice is the .

[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Compare the shape of the histogram to the three choices. Is there anything that indicates that the modal interval tells us more about the data than the estimated mean or the median interval?

STEP: Examine the meaning of each measure of central tendency
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to determine which one of the three measures of central tendency is most appropriate for the data shown in the histogram. In other words, which one gives the best summary of the data?

Each measure of central tendency tells us something specific about a data set. Sometimes one measure is better than another because of how the data are spread out. Generally we decide which one to use by making sure that we do not hide an important fact about the data.

Here are key things to consider about the different measures of central tendency:

  • The estimated mean always represents every data value in the set. The mean is the most common measure of central tendency. Use it unless there is a good reason not to.

    • Do not use if there is a very tall modal interval with no other tall bars.
    • Do not use if there are outliers that drag the mean away from a central part of the data.

  • The modal interval ignores the role of values outside of the modal interval. It focuses on the most common values.

    • Use if there is a single interval which dominates (is much taller than) all other intervals. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.
    • Use if there is more than one modal interval to show that the data have more than one peak. We should not use the mean because it would hide this fact.

    • Use if the data are shifted to one side or the other (not symmetric around the middle).

The median is usually the best choice for data which rate something. This is because the median splits the values into lower and upper halves. If the median interval for data on a scale of 1 to 10 is the interval 2≤r<42≤r<4 then we know most people were quite unimpressed with the book: half of the ratings were below approximately 3 stars. If the median interval is 8≤r<108≤r<10 then we know that the book was very popular. Compare that to the mean: even if the median interval was 8≤r<108≤r<10, if there are outlying low ratings they will pull the mean down, for example, perhaps near 6,26,2. That would indicate a pretty good movie, but not as strongly as the median does.

NOTE: It is crucial to be aware that the meaning of the median interval is part of the reason why it is the best choice. The median interval is the best choice partly because we know that the median interval contains the middle value. If we identify the median interval as the best choice, we are saying that the modal interval is not as important and the estimated mean is impacted by certain values in a way that makes it less useful.

The most appropriate choice is the median interval.

A the single interval which comes at the beginning.
B the interval or intervals which contains the most data values.
C the value we get from adding everything up and dividing by the total number.
D the interval or intervals with no data values in it.
Answer: The correct choice is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

The modal interval is named after the mode. What is the mode of a data set?

STEP: Select the correct description of the modal interval
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The name modal interval is based on the word mode. The mode of a data set is the value or values in the data set which occur most. The modal interval is similar to the mode but it is for grouped data.

The modal interval is the interval or intervals which contains the most data values. The figure below shows data grouped into 55 intervals.

The modal intervals are shown above. In this case there are three modal intervals. Note that the bars for these intervals all have the same height. All three contain 88 values.

NOTE: If there is more than one bar which is the tallest, there must be multiple modal intervals.

The correct statement is: The modal interval is the interval or intervals which contains the most data values. So the answer is B.

Estimating the mean for grouped data

A set of data is represented in the table below. There are 1010 data values and they are grouped into 55 intervals.

Interval Frequency
0≤x<60≤x<622
6≤x<126≤x<1222
12≤x<1812≤x<1822
18≤x<2418≤x<2422
24≤x<3024≤x<3022

Answer the following questions about this frequency table.

  1. Estimate the mean value of the data from the table.

    Answer: The estimated mean = .
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

    The definition of the mean is the sum of a set of values, divided by the number of values in the set. So start by finding the sum and number of values in the table.

    STEP: Find the midpoints of the intervals
    [−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

    In this question we are given a frequency table, and asked to estimate the mean value of the data.

    The mean of a set of values is the sum of the values, divided by the number of values in the data set. So the first step is to calculate the sum of all the values.

    The values in the frequency table have been grouped. This means that we do not know the exact values of the data points. We only know which interval the data fall into. So we have to assume that every point in each group has the average value for that group; this is the midpoint of the interval.

    Interval Frequency
    0≤x<60≤x<6
    Midpoint: 33     		22
    6≤x<126≤x<12
    Midpoint: 99     		22
    12≤x<1812≤x<18
    Midpoint: 1515     		22
    18≤x<2418≤x<24
    Midpoint: 2121     		22
    24≤x<3024≤x<30
    Midpoint: 2727     		22
    STEP: Calculate the estimated mean
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

    To get the estimated mean of the values in each group, we multiply the frequency in each group by the interval midpoint. The sum of all the values is an estimate for the sum of the real data values.

    Sum=((3⋅2)+(9⋅2)+(15⋅2)+(21⋅2)+(27⋅2))
    Sum=⎛⎝⎜⎜(3⋅2)+(9⋅2)+(15⋅2)+(21⋅2)+(27⋅2)⎞⎠⎟⎟

    We then divide this value by the total number of values in the data set. We are told in the question that there are 1010 values in the data set.

    Number=10
    Number=10

    So now we have all the pieces we need to calculate the estimated mean.

    Estimatedmean=SumNumber=15010=15
    Estimatedmean=SumNumber=15010=15

    So the estimated mean value of the data is 1515.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Is the value calculated in Question 1 the exact value of the mean for the data set? Choose a reason from the table below.

    Reason
    A The calculation uses the midpoints in place of the data values.
    B There is no true mean since we don't know the data.
    C Statistics are always true.
    Answer:

    The answer to Question 1 exact, because of Reason .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Did you use the exact values in your calculation for Question 1? Or did you have to make some assumptions?

    STEP: Identify the difference between exact and estimated mean
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    When we have data grouped into intervals, we do not know the exact values of each of the data points. Instead, we only know the interval in which each value lies.

    When we calculate the exact mean of a data set, we use the exact values of the data points. But for grouped data, we do not know the individual data values. So we use the midpoints of the intervals instead. This is an estimation and it usually gives a different result from the true mean.

    It is possible that the estimated mean will be equal to the true mean. But if that happens it is a coincidence. And since we do not know the original data, we would not even know that the estimated mean was equal to the exact value!

    The correct answer is that the estimated mean value is not exact, because the calculation uses the midpoints in place of the data values (Reason A).

Estimating the mean for grouped data

A set of data is represented in the table below. There are 2525 data values and they are grouped into 55 intervals.

Interval Frequency
0≤x<20≤x<266
2≤x<42≤x<422
4≤x<64≤x<677
6≤x<86≤x<866
8≤x<108≤x<1044

Answer the following questions about this frequency table.

  1. Estimate the mean value of the data from the table.

    Answer: The estimated mean = .
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

    The definition of the mean is the sum of a set of values, divided by the number of values in the set. So start by finding the sum and number of values in the table.

    STEP: Find the midpoints of the intervals
    [−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

    In this question we are given a frequency table, and asked to estimate the mean value of the data.

    The mean of a set of values is the sum of the values, divided by the number of values in the data set. So the first step is to calculate the sum of all the values.

    The values in the frequency table have been grouped. This means that we do not know the exact values of the data points. We only know which interval the data fall into. So we have to assume that every point in each group has the average value for that group; this is the midpoint of the interval.

    Interval Frequency
    0≤x<20≤x<2
    Midpoint: 11     		66
    2≤x<42≤x<4
    Midpoint: 33     		22
    4≤x<64≤x<6
    Midpoint: 55     		77
    6≤x<86≤x<8
    Midpoint: 77     		66
    8≤x<108≤x<10
    Midpoint: 99     		44
    STEP: Calculate the estimated mean
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

    To get the estimated mean of the values in each group, we multiply the frequency in each group by the interval midpoint. The sum of all the values is an estimate for the sum of the real data values.

    Sum=((1⋅6)+(3⋅2)+(5⋅7)+(7⋅6)+(9⋅4))
    Sum=⎛⎝⎜⎜(1⋅6)+(3⋅2)+(5⋅7)+(7⋅6)+(9⋅4)⎞⎠⎟⎟

    We then divide this value by the total number of values in the data set. We are told in the question that there are 2525 values in the data set.

    Number=25
    Number=25

    So now we have all the pieces we need to calculate the estimated mean.

    Estimatedmean=SumNumber=12525=5
    Estimatedmean=SumNumber=12525=5

    So the estimated mean value of the data is 55.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Is the value calculated in Question 1 the exact value of the mean for the data set? Choose a reason from the table below.

    Reason
    A There is no true mean since we don't know the data.
    B The estimated mean is always the same as the mean.
    C The calculation uses the midpoints in place of the data values.
    Answer:

    The answer to Question 1 exact, because of Reason .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Did you use the exact values in your calculation for Question 1? Or did you have to make some assumptions?

    STEP: Identify the difference between exact and estimated mean
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    When we have data grouped into intervals, we do not know the exact values of each of the data points. Instead, we only know the interval in which each value lies.

    When we calculate the exact mean of a data set, we use the exact values of the data points. But for grouped data, we do not know the individual data values. So we use the midpoints of the intervals instead. This is an estimation and it usually gives a different result from the true mean.

    It is possible that the estimated mean will be equal to the true mean. But if that happens it is a coincidence. And since we do not know the original data, we would not even know that the estimated mean was equal to the exact value!

    The correct answer is that the estimated mean value is not exact, because the calculation uses the midpoints in place of the data values (Reason C).

Drawing conclusions based on grouped data

The table below summarises the number of goals scored in one season by 2020 teams in a soccer league. The values fall into five intervals each with a width of 20 goals20 goals. Data values are integers.

Interval (goalsgoals) Frequency
0≤n<200≤n<2044
20≤n<4020≤n<4066
40≤n<6040≤n<6044
60≤n<8060≤n<8022
80≤n<10080≤n<10044

What is the best that we can say about the number of teams with a goal total greater than or equal to 100 goals100 goals? In other words, what is the most precise conclusion about the number of teams with a goal total greater than or equal to 100 goals100 goals? Select the best answer from the choices below.

The number of values is...
A zero: there are no values greater than or equal to 100 goals100 goals.
B at least −1−1 but possibly as many as 66.
C at least −1−1 but less than 66.
D no greater than 00.
Answer: The best statement is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Remember that we do not know any details about the data values inside the intervals. For example, we do not know if the 66 values in the second interval are all equal to 2020, if they are all equal to 3939, if they are scattered around from 2020 to 3939, or whatever other possibility. That means there is usually a limit to how much we can know for sure.

STEP: Think about the number of values which can be greater than or equal to 100 goals100 goals
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

When dealing with grouped data, it is important to be able to know how many data values there are above or below a given value. In this question we need to figure out the number of teams with a goal total greater than or equal to 100 goals100 goals. So the number 100100 indicates a boundary and we want to know how many values in the data are above or on that boundary.

In this case, the boundary is the upper boundary of the entire table (the upper limit of the final interval).

There are no values equal to 100 goals100 goals and there are no values greater than 100 goals100 goals. Remember that the final interval is 80≤n<10080≤n<100, which does not include 100 goals100 goals!

For the number of teams with a goal total greater than or equal to 100 goals100 goals, the most we know is that the number of values is zero: there are no values greater than or equal to 100 goals100 goals. So the correct answer is Choice A.

Grouped data and the median

The following table shows 1111 data values grouped into 44 intervals. Each interval is 33 wide. All data values are integers.

Intervals Frequencies
0≤x<30≤x<322
3≤x<63≤x<644
6≤x<96≤x<922
9≤x<129≤x<1233

  1. Is it possible that the median of the data set is 44?

    Answer: Could the median be equal to 44?
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Start by figuring out which interval the median is in.

    STEP: Find the interval which contains the median
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    We need to determine whether or not 44 could be the median for the data summarised in the table. The median of a data set is the value which falls in the middle of the data when the data are in order (from smallest to largest).

    We cannot find the true median of the data because we do not know all of the data values. But we can find the interval in which the median must be located. We know from the question that there are 1111 data values. If there are 1111 values, the middle value must be the sixth value (with 55 data values on each side of it)! So the data look something like this:

    1;2;……⏟middle……;10;10⏟↑5 smallestvaluesmedianhere5 largestvalues
    1;2;……5 smallestvaluesmiddle↑medianhere……;10;105 largestvalues

    We need to work our way through the data values starting at the first interval until we reach the interval with the sixth value in it. There are 22 data values in the first interval. That is less than 66, so to get to the median we must continue into the second interval. The second interval contains 44 more data values. So the first and second intervals together have 66 data values. So the median is in the second interval. (In fact, the median is the last value in the second interval, because the first two intervals together contain exactly 66 values.)

    The median must be in the interval 3≤x<63≤x<6.

    STEP: Determine if 44 is in that interval or not
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The median is in the interval 3≤x<63≤x<6. And that means the median might be any number from 33 up to but not including 55. Is 44 in this interval?

    Yes it is. So it is possible that 44 is the median value in the data set.

    NOTE: We cannot know the true median because the data are grouped. We only know that the median is somewhere in the interval 3≤x<63≤x<6.

    The correct answer for whether or not the median can be 44 is: Yes, it is possible.
